notesStmt.note: This manuscript may have been composed in 1861, since Whitman describes how a decision to secede from the Union will affect an individual state.
The manuscript leaf is mounted on a backing sheet, making the verso inaccessible.

body.p: The lesson is a profound one. The union is proved solid by proofs that none can gainsay. Every state that permits her faction of secessionists to carry her out, shrivels and wilts at once. Her credit is the first thing that goes. A reign of terror is inaugurated. All trade, all business stops. Travel, by the usual routes, is done.suspended. The best and many of the wealthiest citizens escape by flight. Incomes are not paid to widows, orphans, and old persons. The arm of the law dares notceases to lift itself, in any one's protection. The devils are unloosed. Theft, outrage, assassination, stalk around, not in the night only, but in open day.
